facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 81 of 1953 was filed under article 132(1) of the Constitution of India.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 81 of 1953. Appeal under article 132 1  of the Constitution of India from the Judgment and Order, dated the 18th April, 1951, of the High Court

facts.text: Appeal is from the Judgment and Order dated 18th April 1951 of the High Court of Judicature for the State of Orissa at Cuttack in Judicial Case No. 60 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal under article 132 1  of the Constitution of India from the Judgment and Order, dated the 18th April, 1951, of the High Court of Judicature for the State of Orissa at Cuttack in Judicial Case No. 60 of 1951.

facts.text: The appellant is a legal practitioner residing within the limits of the Kendrapara Municipality and practising as a mukhtar in the criminal and revenue Courts there.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by BHAGWATI J.-The appellant who is a legal practitioner residing within the limits of the Kendrapara Municipality and practising as a mukhtar in the criminal and the revenue Courts there filed his

facts.text: Appellant filed his nomination paper for election as a Councillor of the Municipality on 15th March 1951.

anchor.surface_text: practising as a mukhtar in the criminal and the revenue Courts there filed his numberination paper for election as a Councillor of the Municipality on the 15th March, 1951.

facts.text: Nomination paper was rejected by the Election Officer on 25th March 1951.

anchor.surface_text: on the 15th March, 1951. That numberination paper was rejected by the Election Officer on the 25th March, 1951, on the ground that he was employed as a legal practitioner

facts.text: Rejection ground: appellant was employed as a legal practitioner against the Municipality in case US 198 of the Bihar and Orissa Municipal Act pending in the Sub-Divisional Magistrate Court.

anchor.surface_text: Officer on the 25th March, 1951, on the ground that he was employed as a legal practitioner against the Municipality in a case U S 198 of the Bihar and Orissa Municipal Act which was pending in the Sub-Divisional Magistrate Court.

facts.text: Appellant filed petition before High Court of Orissa on 4th April 1951 under article 226 praying for writ of prohibition to State Government and Election Officer.

anchor.surface_text: Magistrate Court. The appellant then filed on the 4th April, 1951, a petition before the High Court of Orissa under article 226 of the Constitution praying that a writ or order of prohibition be issued to the State Government and the Election Officer

facts.text: High Court rejected the petition but granted certificate under article 132(1) for leave to appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: This petition was rejected by the High Court but the High Court granted the appellant a certificate under article 132 1  of the Constitution for leave to appeal to this Court.

facts.text: Orissa Municipal Act 1950 (Orissa Act 23 of 1950) received assent of Governor on 7th November 1950 and published on 11th November 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The Orissa Municipal Act, 1950  Orissa Act 23 of 1950  was passed by the local Legislature and received the assent of the Governor on the 7th November, 1950, and was published in the official gazette on the 11th November, 1950.

facts.text: Section 16 of the Act prescribes disqualification: no person qualified if employed as paid legal practitioner on behalf of or against the Municipality.

anchor.surface_text: Section 16 of the Act prescribes the disqualifications of candidates for election and provides No person shall be qualified for election to a seat in a Municipality, if such person  ix   is employed as a paid legal practitioner on behalf of the Municipality or as legal practitioner against the Municipality

facts.text: On 11th November 1950, Secretary to Government Local Self-Government Dept addressed letter No.1336/L.S.G. to all District Magistrates intimating general elections on adult suffrage in 12 municipalities including Kendrapara.

anchor.surface_text: On the 11th November, 1950, the Secretary to the Government, Local Self-Government Department addressed to all District Magistrates of the State letter No. 1336/L.S.G. intimating that the Government had decided that general elections should be held on the basis of adult suffrage as provided in the Act in 12 Municipalities including the Kendrapara Municipality.

facts.text: Notification No.2015 L.S.G. issued on 13th December 1950 under section 13 r/w section 1(5) fixing 1st March 1950 as relevant date for voters' residential qualification.

anchor.surface_text: Notification No. 2015 L.S.G. was issued on the 13th December, 1950, under section 13 read with section 1  5  of the Act fixing- the 1st day of March, 1950, as the relevant date for voters in the election as regards their residential qualification in the Municipality.

facts.text: Notification No.65 L.S.G. issued on 4th January 1951 publishing Municipal Election Rules 1950 under section 387(2)(1) and (2).

anchor.surface_text: Notification No. 65 L.S.G. issued on the 4th January, 1951, published rules made in exercise of the powers companyferred by clauses  1  and  2  of sub-section  2  of section 387 of the Act called the Municipal Election Rules, 1950.

facts.text: Redistribution of wards effected by Notification No.167 L.S.G. dated 10th January 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Redistribution of wards was effected by Notification No. 167 L.S.G. dated the 10th January, 1951, and two Notifications Nos. 519 and 521 L.S.G. were issued on the 24th January, 1951, fixing

facts.text: Notifications Nos.519 and 521 L.S.G. issued on 24th January 1951 fixing numbers of Councillors and reserved seats for each Municipality.

anchor.surface_text: Notification No. 167 L.S.G. dated the 10th January, 1951, and two Notifications Nos. 519 and 521 L.S.G. were issued on the 24th January, 1951, fixing 1007 the numbers of Councillors and of the reserved seats for each Municipality.

facts.text: 15th March 1951 fixed as date for filing nominations.

anchor.surface_text: The 15th March, 1951, was fixed as the date for filing the numberinations and the 25th March, 1951, for scrutiny of numberination papers.

facts.text: 25th March 1951 fixed for scrutiny of nomination papers.

anchor.surface_text: filing the numberinations and the 25th March, 1951, for scrutiny of numberination papers. The 20th April, 1951, was the date fixed for the holding of the election.

facts.text: 20th April 1951 fixed as date for holding the election.

anchor.surface_text: papers. The 20th April, 1951, was the date fixed for the holding of the election. All these steps were taken by the Government in anticipation acting under the powers reserved under section 1  5  of the Act

facts.text: Act extended to Kendrapara Municipality on 15th April 1951 by notification under section 1(3).

anchor.surface_text: it was only on the 15th April, 1951, that the Act was extended to the Kendrapara Municipality by a numberification under section 1  3  of the Act.

facts.text: Appellant contended that Act had not come into operation in Kendrapara till 15th April 1951, so disqualification not incurred on 15th March 1951.

anchor.surface_text: when he filed his numberination paper, that the rejection of his numberination paper therefore on that ground by the Election Officer on the 25th March, 1951, was illegal and numberelection companyld be held on the 20th April, 1951,

facts.text: High Court negatived both contentions of appellant.

facts.text: Judgment of Supreme Court delivered on 25 November 1954 by Bhagwati J.

anchor.surface_text: Porus A. Mehta and P. g. Gokhale for the respondent. 1954. November 25. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by BHAGWATI J.-The appellant who is a legal practitioner residing

facts.text: Section 1(5) of the Act provides that elections could be held under the Act after assent but take effect on coming into force.

anchor.surface_text: Section 1  5  of the Act in express terms provides that after the Act has received the assent of the Governor elections companyld be held under the Act but were only to take effect on the Act companying into force,

anchor.surface_text: Section I of the Act runs as under 1006 This Act may be called the Orissa Municipal Act, 1950. It shall extend to the whole of the State of Orissa. It shall companye into force in such area or areas on such date or dates as the State Government may appoint from time to time Any numberification, order or rule and any appointment to an office, may be made or election held under this Act, after it shall have received the assent of the Governor and shall take effect on this Act companying into force.

concepts.interpretation: Permits holding of elections, notifications, rules and preliminary steps after assent of Governor even before the Act comes into force in a particular area; such steps validated by necessary implication; elections take effect only on commencement

anchor.surface_text: Article 14 forbids class legislation but does number forbid reasonable classification for the purposes of legislation. That classification however cannot be arbitrary but must rest upon some real and substantial distinction bearing a reasonable and just relation to the things in respect of which the classification is made. In other words the classification must have a reasonable relation to the object or the purpose sought to be achieved by the impugned legislation.

issues.text: Whether the Orissa Municipal Act, 1950 had come into operation in Kendrapara Municipality before 15th April 1951 so as to validate rejection of nomination under section 16(1)(ix) and holding of election under the Act and Rules

anchor.surface_text: The appellant contended  1  that the Act had number come into operation in the Kendrapara Municipality till the 15th April, 1951, that the disqualification- prescribed by section 16 1   ix  companyld number consequently have been incurred by him on the 15th March, 1951, when he filed his numberination paper, that the rejection of his numberination paper therefore on that ground by the Election Officer on the 25th March, 1951, was illegal

issues.text: Whether the disqualification under section 16(1)(ix) of the Orissa Municipal Act, 1950 violated fundamental rights under Articles 14 and 19(1)(g) of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: and  2  that in any event the disqualification prescribed under section 16 1   ix  of the Act violated his fundamentals rights guaranteed under article 14 and article 19 1   g  of the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether the classification of legal practitioners employed for or against the Municipality under section 16(1)(ix) is reasonable under Article 14

anchor.surface_text: Article 14 forbids class legislation but does number forbid reasonable classification for the purposes of legislation. That classification however cannot be arbitrary but must rest upon some real and substantial distinction bearing a reasonable and just relation to the things in respect of which the classification is made.

issues.text: Whether the disqualification under section 16(1)(ix) violates the right to practise profession under Article 19(1)(g)

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court agrees with High Court's rejection

holdings.text: The preliminary steps taken under the Orissa Municipal Act, 1950 for holding elections, including scrutiny of nominations and application of disqualifications under section 16(1)(ix), were validated by section 1(5) even before the Act came into force in the Kendrapara Municipality

anchor.surface_text: Section 1 5 of the Act in express terms provides that after the Act has received the assent of the Governor elections could be held under the Act but were only to take effect on the Act coming into force, which means the coming into force of the Act in such area

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 1(5) expressly authorizes elections and by necessary implication all preliminary steps after Governor's assent, though effective only on commencement in the area; section 1(3) postpones rest of Act but not 1(5)

holdings.text: The disqualification under section 16(1)(ix) does not violate Articles 14 or 19(1)(g) of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: The contention that the disqualification prescribed in section 16 1 ix violates the fundamental rights of the appellant under article 14 and article 19 1 g is equally untenable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Classification reasonable under Article 14; no fundamental right to contest election under Article 19(1)(g); any restriction reasonable under Article 19(5)

holdings.text: The classification of paid legal practitioners for or against the Municipality under section 16(1)(ix) is reasonable and has rational relation to the legislative object of ensuring purity of public life by avoiding conflict of interest and duty

anchor.surface_text: Article 14 forbids class legislation but does not forbid reasonable classification for the purposes of legislation. That classification however cannot be arbitrary but must rest upon some real and substantial distinction bearing a reasonable and just relation to the things

holdings.reasoning_summary: Classification rests on real distinction with reasonable relation to object; Legislature not required to cover all possible categories of conflict

holdings.text: Omitting other categories with potential conflict from disqualification under section 16(1) does not render section 16(1)(ix) discriminatory under Article 14

anchor.surface_text: It was however urged that besides this category there are also other categories where there would be a possibility of conflict between interest and duty and that in so far as they were not covered by the disqualifications prescribed by section 16 1 of the Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislature may select categories to address without making law all-embracing; omission of others on same footing does not violate Article 14

holdings.text: Section 16(1)(ix) does not violate Article 19(1)(g) as there is no fundamental right to stand for election and the disqualification only requires divesting conflicting briefs

anchor.surface_text: The right of the appellant to practise the profession of law guaranteed by article 19 1 g cannot be said to have been violated, because in laying down the disqualification in section 16 1 ix of the Act the Legislature does not prevent him from practising

holdings.reasoning_summary: Article 19(1)(g) protects practice of profession but not candidature; proper to require divestment of conflicting employment to contest

holdings.text: Any restriction imposed by section 16(1)(ix) on right to practise profession is reasonable under Article 19(5) in interests of general public for preservation of purity in public life

anchor.surface_text: Even if it be taken as a restriction on his right to practice his profession of law, such restriction would be a reasonable one and well within the ambit of article 19 clause 5. Such restriction would be a reasonable one to impose in the interests

holdings.reasoning_summary: Restriction preserves purity of public life and avoids conflict, falling within permitted reasonable restrictions for general public
